{{short description|Persecution of and discrimination against people identified as atheists}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2020}} [[File:Map of countries with death penalty for atheists.svg|thumb|alt=Atheist Death Penalty Map|right|upright=1.35|Countries in which [[apostasy]] or [[blasphemy]] against the local or state religion was punishable by execution under the law as of 2013. Currently, this occurs only in some [[Apostasy in Islam|Muslim-majority]] countries and Muslim-majority states in Northern [[Nigeria]].<ref name= Indy1 >{{cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/the-13-countries-where-being-an-atheist-is-punishable-by-death-a6960561.html |title= The 13 countries where being an atheist is punishable by death |date= 30 March 2016 |first1= Siobhan |last1= Fenton |work= [[The Independent]] |access-date= 23 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="reuters131210"/><ref name= "iheu report"/><ref name= FreethoughtReport>{{cite web |url= http://freethoughtreport.com/download-the-report/ |title= The Freedom of Thought Report |date= 2015 |publisher= [[International Humanist and Ethical Union]] |access-date = 20 November 2016}}</ref>]] {{Atheism sidebar|expanded=concepts}} {{Discrimination sidebar|Religious}} '''Discrimination against atheists''', both at present and historically, includes [[Religious persecution|persecution]] of and [[Religious discrimination|discrimination]] against people who are identified as [[Atheism|atheists]]. Discrimination against atheists may also comprise negative attitudes, prejudice, hostility, hatred, fear, or intolerance towards atheists and atheism.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Atheists in Lebanon|url=https://www.freethoughtlebanon.net/category/atheists-in-lebanon/|access-date=2021-04-25|website=Freethought Lebanon|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Somin|first=Ilya|title=Atheists May Be the Most Unpopular Minority|url=https://www.law.gmu.edu/assets/files/faculty/Somin_LegalTimes_Prejudice.pdf}}</ref> Because atheism can be defined in various ways, those discriminated against or persecuted on the grounds of being atheists might not have been considered atheists in a different time or place. Thirteen Muslim countries officially punish atheism or apostasy by death and [[Humanists International]] asserts that "the overwhelming majority" of the 193 [[member states of the United Nations]] "at best discriminate against citizens who have no belief in a god and at worst can jail them for offences dubbed blasphemy".<ref name="reuters131210"/>
In some [[Muslim world|Muslim-majority countries]], atheists face persecution and severe penalties such as the withdrawal of [[Status (law)|legal status]] or, in the case of [[Apostasy in Islam|apostasy]], [[Capital punishment#Islam|capital punishment]].<ref name="Jakarta Globe">{{cite web | title = 'God Does Not Exist' Comment Ends Badly for Indonesia Man | url = http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/god-does-not-exist-comment-ends-badly-for-indonesia-man/492370 | access-date = 2012-01-20}}</ref>
==Other names== Sometimes such discrimination is called '''atheophobia''',<ref>{{cite book |first=Barney |last=Warf |year=2015 |chapter=Atheist Geographies and Geographies of Atheism |title=The Changing World Religion Map |editor1=Stanley D. Brunn |editor2=Donna A. Gilbreath |volume=4 |page=2225 |isbn=978-94-017-9375-9 |via=Amazon.com |quote=[...] to openly discriminate against them [atheists], or practice atheophobia.}}</ref> '''atheistophobia''',<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bomi2eh7xocC&q=atheistophobia&pg=PA291|title=Rhetoric and Argumentation in the Beginning of the XX Century|last=Ribeiro|first=Henrique Jales|date=2009-12-01|publisher=Imprensa da Universidade de Coimbra / Coimbra University Press|isbn=9789898074775|language=en}}</ref> '''anti-atheism''', '''anti-atheist discrimination'''.<ref>{{cite book |first1=Ryan T. |last1=Cragun |author2=Joseph H. Hammer |author3=Jesse M. Smith |year=2013 |chapter=North America |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jbIVAgAAQBAJ&q=anti-atheism%20discrimination&pg=PA615 |title=The Oxford Handbook of Atheism |editor1=Stephen Bullivant |editor2=Michael Ruse |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=xiii, 615+ |isbn=9780199644650 |access-date=13 February 2017 |via=Google Books }}</ref>
==Ancient times== [[Tim Whitmarsh]] argues atheism existed in the [[Ancient history|ancient world]], though it remains difficult to assess its extent given that atheists are referenced (usually disparagingly) rather than having surviving writings. Given [[monotheism]] at the time was a minority view, atheism generally attacked [[polytheism|polytheistic]] beliefs and associated practices in references found. The word "atheos" (godless) also was used for religious dissent generally (including the monotheists) which complicates study further. Despite these difficulties, Whitmarsh believes that otherwise atheism then was much the same. While atheists (or people perceived as such) were occasionally persecuted, this was rare (perhaps due to being a small group, plus a relative tolerance toward different religious views).<ref name="whitmarsh">{{cite book|last=Whitmarsh|first=Tim|title=Battling the Gods: Atheism in the Ancient World|publisher=Knopf|year=2015|isbn=978-0-307-95833-4}}</ref> Other scholars believe it arose later in the [[early modern period|modern era]]. [[Lucien Febvre]] has referred to the "unthinkability" of atheism in its strongest sense before the sixteenth century, because of the "deep religiosity" of that era. [[Karen Armstrong]] has concurred, writing "from birth and baptism to death and burial in the churchyard, religion dominated the life of every single man and woman. Every activity of the day, which was punctuated by church bells summoning the faithful to prayer, was saturated with religious beliefs and institutions: they dominated professional and public life—even the guilds and the universities were religious organizations. ... Even if an exceptional man could have achieved the objectivity necessary to question the nature of religion and the existence of God, he would have found no support in either the philosophy or the science of his time."<ref name="davidson">{{cite book|last=Davidson|first=Nicholas|title=Atheism from the Reformation to the Enlightenment|editor=Michael Hunter |editor2=David Wootton|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1992|pages=55–86|chapter=Unbelief and Atheism in Italy|isbn=978-0-19-822736-6}}</ref><ref name="books.google">{{cite book|last=Armstrong |first=Karen |title=A History of God: The 4000-year Quest of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam |publisher=Random House, Inc. |pages=286–87|year=1994|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_n3cCF2I2FUC&q=A+History+of+God| isbn=978-0-345-38456-0}}</ref><ref name="kelley">{{cite book|last=Kelley|first=Donald R. |title=Frontiers of History: Historical Inquiry in the Twentieth Century |publisher=Yale University Press|year=2006|page=115|isbn=978-0-300-12062-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K-wVctit5U8C&pg=PA115}}</ref> As governmental authority rested on the notion of [[Divine right of kings|divine right]], it was threatened by those who denied the existence of the local god. Those labeled as atheist, including early Christians and Muslims, were as a result targeted for legal persecution.<ref name="gey 250">{{cite book|last=Gey|first=Steven G.|title=The Cambridge Companion to Atheism|editor=Martin, Michael|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2007|chapter=Atheism and the Freedom of Religion|pages=250–253, 260–2 |isbn=978-0-521-84270-9|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tAeFipOVx4MC&pg=PA250}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Armstrong |first=Karen |title=A History of God: The 4000-year Quest of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam |publisher=Random House, Inc. |pages=98, 147|year=1994|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_n3cCF2I2FUC|isbn=978-0-345-38456-0}}</ref>
==Early modern period and Reformation== {{Further|Atheism in the Age of Enlightenment}} During the [[early modern period]], the term "atheist" was used as an insult and applied to a broad range of people, including those who held opposing theological beliefs, as well as those who had committed [[suicide]], immoral or self-indulgent people, and even opponents of the belief in [[witchcraft]].<ref name="davidson"/><ref name="books.google"/><ref name="laursen">{{cite book|last=Laursen|first=John Christian |author2=Nederman, Cary J.|title=Beyond the Persecuting Society: Religious Toleration Before the Enlightenment |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|year=1997|page=142|isbn= 978-0-8122-1567-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r2j6ZHgXZWkC&pg=PA142}}</ref> Atheistic beliefs were seen as threatening to order and society by philosophers such as [[Thomas Aquinas]]. Lawyer and scholar [[Thomas More]] said that religious tolerance should be extended to all except those who did not believe in a deity or the immortality of the soul.<ref name="gey 250"/> [[John Locke]], a founder of modern notions of religious liberty, argued that atheists (as well as Catholics and Muslims) should not be granted full citizenship rights.<ref name="gey 250"/>
During the [[Inquisition]], several of those who were accused of atheism or blasphemy, or both, were tortured or executed. These included the priest [[Giulio Cesare Vanini]] who was strangled and burned in 1619 and the Polish nobleman [[Kazimierz Łyszczyński]] who was executed in Warsaw,<ref name="davidson"/><ref name="brooke">{{cite book|last= Brooke|first=John Hedley|others= Maclean, Ian |title=Heterodoxy in Early Modern Science and Religion |publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-19-926897-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W9o_OEvMQTcC&pg=PA66}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Kłoczowski |first=Jerzy |title=A History of Polish Christianity |publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2000 |page=155|isbn=978-0-521-36429-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecdye8hk_tgC&pg=PA155}}</ref> as well as [[Etienne Dolet]], a Frenchman executed in 1546. Though heralded as atheist martyrs during the nineteenth century, recent scholars hold that the beliefs espoused by Dolet and Vanini are not atheistic in modern terms.<ref name="kelley"/><ref name="onfray">{{cite book|last=Onfray|first=Michel|others=Leggatt, Jeremy (translator) |title=Atheist manifesto: the case against Christianity, Judaism, and Islam |publisher=Arcade Publishing|year=2007|page=24|isbn=978-1-55970-820-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QpEAYMo7pFkC&pg=PA24}}</ref><ref name="chadwich">{{cite book|last=Chadwick |first=Owen |title=The Early Reformation on the Continent By |publisher= Oxford University Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0-19-926578-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VR1yNW8mgoEC&pg=PA413}}</ref>
[[Baruch Spinoza]] was effectively excommunicated from the [[Sephardic Jewish]] community of [[Amsterdam]] for atheism, though he did not claim to be an atheist.
== Modern era == === Victorian Britain === {{Further|Irreligion in the United Kingdom}} During the nineteenth century, British atheists, though few in number, were subject to discriminatory practices.<ref name="cookson">{{cite book | author = Larson, Timothy | chapter = Victorian England | title = Encyclopedia of religious freedom | editor = Cookson, Catharine | publisher = Routledge | location = New York | year = 2003 | isbn = 978-0-415-94181-5 | chapter-url = https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofre0000unse | url-access = registration | url = https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofre0000unse }}</ref> The poet [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]] was expelled from the University of Oxford and denied custody of his two children after publishing a pamphlet titled ''[[The Necessity of Atheism]]''.<ref name="gey253" /> Those not willing to swear Christian oaths during judicial proceedings were unable to give evidence in court to obtain justice until this requirement was repealed by Acts passed in 1869 and 1870.<ref name="cookson"/>
Atheist [[Charles Bradlaugh]] was elected as a [[Member of Parliament (UK)|Member of the British Parliament]] in 1880. He was denied the right to affirm rather than swear his oath of office, and was then denied the ability to swear the oath as other Members objected that he had himself said it would be meaningless. Bradlaugh was re-elected three times before he was finally able to take his seat in 1886 when the Speaker of the House permitted him to take the oath.<ref name="gey253">{{cite book|last=Gey|first=Steven G.|title=The Cambridge Companion to Atheism|editor=Martin, Michael|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2007|chapter=Atheism and the Freedom of Religion|pages=253–255|isbn=978-0-521-84270-9|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tAeFipOVx4MC&pg=PA253}}</ref>
=== Nazi Germany === {{Further|Religion in Nazi Germany}} In [[Nazi Germany|Germany during the Nazi era]], a 1933 decree stated that "No National Socialist may suffer detriment... on the ground that he does not make any religious profession at all".<ref name="Baynes"/> However, the regime strongly opposed "godless communism",<ref>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Christian|title=Disruptive religion: the force of faith in social-movement activism|publisher=Routledge|year=1996|pages=156–57|isbn=978-0-415-91405-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=39SoSG4NGAoC&pg=PA156}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Stackelberg|first=Roderick|title=The Routledge Companion to Nazi Germany|publisher=Routledge|year=2007|pages=136–8|isbn=978-0-415-30860-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cpXIR9yOMuoC&pg=PA136}}</ref> and all of Germany's atheist and largely left-wing [[freethought]] organizations such as the [[German Freethinkers League]] (500,000 members)<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1933/05/14/archives/atheist-hall-converted-berlin-churches-establish-bureau-to-win-back.html |title=Atheist Hall Converted: Berlin Churches Establish Bureau to Win Back Worshipers |work=The New York Times |date=14 May 1933 |page=2 |access-date=18 September 2010}}</ref> were banned the same year; some right-wing groups were tolerated by the Nazis until the mid-1930s.<ref name="may">{{cite book |last= Bock| first= Heike | chapter= Secularization of the modern conduct of life? Reflections on the religiousness of early modern Europe| editor=Hanne May |title=Religiosität in der säkularisierten Welt |publisher=VS Verlag fnr Sozialw |year=2006 |page= 157|isbn=978-3-8100-4039-8 |chapter-url= https://books.google.com/books?id=nfQ0pqA53Z8C&pg=PA157}}</ref><ref name=kaiser>{{cite book|last=Kaiser|first=Jochen-Christoph|title=Atheismus und religiöse Indifferenz|editor=Christel Gärtner|publisher=VS Verlag|year=2003|volume=Organisierter Atheismus|pages= 122, 124–6|isbn=978-3-8100-3639-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YXOr4xQFSJsC&pg=PA124}}</ref> In a speech made later in 1933, Hitler claimed to have "stamped out" the atheistic movement.<ref name="Baynes">{{cite book|last=Baynes|first=Norman Hepburn|title=The Speeches of Adolf Hitler, April 1922 – August 1939'|publisher=H. Fertig|year=1969|page=378|quote= Without pledging ourselves to any particular Confession, we have restored faith to its pre-requisites because we were convinced that the people needs [sic] and requires [sic] this faith. We have therefore undertaken the fight against the atheistic movement [Gottlosenbewegung], and that not merely with a few theoretical declarations: we have stamped it out.}}</ref>
During the negotiations which led up to the Nazi-Vatican ''[[Reichskonkordat]]'' of 26 April 1933 Hitler stated that "Secular schools can never be tolerated" because of their irreligious tendencies.<ref>Ernst Helmreich, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=I6DYAAAAMAAJ The German Churches Under Hitler]''. Detroit: Wayne State Univ. Press, 1979, p. 241.</ref> Hitler routinely disregarded this undertaking, and the ''Reichskonkordat'' as a whole, and by 1939, all Catholic denominational schools had been disbanded or converted to public facilities.<ref>Evans, Richard J. (2005). The Third Reich in Power. New York: Penguin. {{ISBN|978-0-14-303790-3}}; pp. 245–246</ref>
By 1939, 94.5% of Germans still called themselves [[Protestantism|Protestant]] or [[Catholic Church|Catholic]], while 3.5% were so-called "''[[Gottgläubig]]e''" (lit. "believers in God") and 1.5% were without faith.<ref name="Ziegler">{{Cite book |last=Ziegler |first=Herbert F. |date=2014 |title=Nazi Germany's New Aristocracy: The SS Leadership, 1925–1939 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBgABAAAQBAJ&pg=PA86 |location=Princeton, New Jersey |publisher=Princeton University Press |pages=85–87 |isbn=9781400860364 |access-date=23 January 2018}}</ref> According to historian [[Richard J. Evans]], those members of the affiliation ''gottgläubig'' "were convinced Nazis who had left their Church at the behest of the Party, which had been trying since the mid-1930s to reduce the influence of Christianity in society".<ref>[[Richard J. Evans]]; ''The Third Reich at War''; Penguin Press; New York 2009, p. 546</ref> [[Heinrich Himmler]] was a strong promoter of the ''gottgläubig'' movement and did not allow atheists into the [[SS]], arguing that their "refusal to acknowledge higher powers" would be a "potential source of indiscipline".<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l5gcZpnL5QUC&q=gottglaubig&pg=PA196|title=The Third Reich|access-date=5 March 2015|isbn=9780330475501|last1=Burleigh|first1=Michael|date=2012-03-22}}</ref> Himmler announced to the [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]: "We believe in a God Almighty who stands above us; he has created the earth, the Fatherland, and the Volk, and he has sent us the Führer. Any human being who does not believe in God should be considered arrogant, megalomaniacal, and stupid and thus not suited for the SS."<ref name="Ziegler"/> The [[SS oath]] (''Eidformel der Schutzstaffel''), written by Himmler, also specifically denounced atheists, repeating the sentiments above.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/Himmler-Heinrich-Die-Schutzstaffel/page/n13/mode/2up|title=Die Schutzstaffel als antibolschewistische Kampforganisation|access-date=5 May 2020|last1=Himmler|first1=Heinrich}}</ref>
==Present day==
===Human rights=== {{main|History of human rights}} {{Further information|Capital punishment for non-violent offenses#Apostasy and blasphemy}} Article 18 of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] is designed to protect the right to freedom of thought, conscience, and religion. In 1993, the UN's human rights committee declared that article 18 of the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] "protects theistic, non-theistic and atheistic beliefs, as well as the right not to profess any religion or belief".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.minorityrights.org/3273/normative-instruments/ccpr-general-comment-22-300793-on-iccpr-article-18.html|title=CCPR General Comment 22: 30/07/93 on ICCPR Article 18|work=Minorityrights.org|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150116043952/http://www.minorityrights.org/3273/normative-instruments/ccpr-general-comment-22-300793-on-iccpr-article-18.html|archive-date=16 January 2015}}</ref> The committee further stated that "the freedom to have or to adopt a religion or belief necessarily entails the freedom to choose a religion or belief, including the right to replace one's current religion or belief with another or to adopt atheistic views". Signatories to the convention are barred from "the use of threat of physical force or penal sanctions to compel believers or non-believers" to recant their beliefs or convert. Despite this, atheists still are persecuted in some parts of the world.<ref name="fdih1">{{cite web |date=1 August 2003|title=Discrimination against religious minorities in Iran|author=International Federation for Human Rights|publisher=fdih.org|access-date=3 March 2009|url=http://www.fidh.org/IMG/pdf/ir0108a.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law2.byu.edu/lawreview/archives/2002/2/dav2.pdf|title=The Evolution of Religious Liberty as a Universal Human Right|access-date=3 March 2009|last=Davis|first=Derek H.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723210828/http://www.law2.byu.edu/lawreview/archives/2002/2/dav2.pdf|archive-date=23 July 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref>
===Western countries=== Modern theories of [[constitutional democracy]] assume that citizens are intellectually and spiritually autonomous and that governments should leave matters of religious belief to individuals and not coerce religious beliefs using sanctions or benefits. The constitutions, human rights conventions and the religious liberty jurisprudence of most constitutional democracies provide legal protection of atheists and agnostics. In addition, freedom of expression provisions and legislation separating church from state also serve to protect the rights of atheists. As a result, open legal discrimination against atheists is not common in most Western countries.<ref name="gey 250" /> However, prejudice against atheists does exist in Western countries. A 2011 study conducted in the United States by the [[UBC|University of British Columbia]] found that believers distrusted atheists as much they did [[rapists]]. The study also showed that atheists had lower employment prospects.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www2.psych.ubc.ca/~ara/Manuscripts/Gervais%20et%20al-%20Atheist%20Distrust.pdf|title=Do You Believe in Atheists? Distrust Is Central to Anti-Atheist Prejudice|first1=Will M.|last1=Gervais|first2=Azim F.|last2=Shariff|first3=Ara|last3=Norenzayan|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|year=2011|volume=101|issue=6|pages=1189–1206|access-date=22 April 2012|doi=10.1037/a0025882|pmid=22059841}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/religion/story/2011-12-10/religion-atheism/51777612/1|title=Study: Atheists distrusted as much as rapists|work=usatoday.com}}{{Dead link|date=July 2022}}</ref>
====Europe==== {{Further|Irreligion in Europe}} In most of Europe, atheists are elected to office at high levels in many governments without controversy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ibka.org/en/articles/miz08/politics-religion-usa|title="Most American secularists have few expectations..." An Interview with AAI president Stuart Bechman|last=Hartmann|first=René|date=March 2008|work=MIZ Magazine|access-date=2009-03-14}}</ref> Some atheist organizations in Europe have expressed concerns regarding issues of separation of church and state, such as administrative fees for leaving the Church charged in Germany,<ref> {{cite web |url=http://ibka.org/en/fee-european-court |title=Fee for leaving church is brought before European Court of Human Rights | I |publisher=International League of Non-religious and Atheists (IBKA) |access-date=2009-03-14}} </ref> and sermons being organized by the Swedish parliament.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.jo.se/Page.aspx?MenuId=106&MainMenuId=106&Language=sv&ObjectClass=DynamX_SFS_Decision&Id=2100 |title = Anmälan till JO – Riksdagens ombudsmän |publisher = jo.se |access-date = 2009-03-14 |url-status = dead |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071122134930/http://www.jo.se/Page.aspx?MenuId=106&MainMenuId=106&Language=sv&ObjectClass=DynamX_SFS_Decision&Id=2100 |archive-date = 22 November 2007 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> Ireland requires religious training from Christian colleges in order to work as a teacher in government-funded schools.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2010/0202/1224263575172.html |title=Why must agnostics be obliged to teach faith? |newspaper=The Irish Times |access-date=2010-02-02 |date=2 February 2010}}</ref> In the UK one-third of state-funded schools are faith-based.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.runnymedetrust.org/uploads/publications/Summaries/RightToDivide-Summary.pdf|title=Right to Divide? Faith Schools and Community Cohesion|last=Berkeley|first=Rob|author2=Savita Vij|date=December 2008|publisher=[[Runnymede Trust]]|page=4|access-date=7 December 2011|location=London}}</ref> However, there are no restrictions on atheists holding public office – the former [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]], [[Nick Clegg]], is an atheist.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peev |first=Gerri |url=http://news.scotsman.com/politics/I-don39t-believe-in-God.3607087.jp |title=Religion: I don't believe in God |work=The Scotsman |date= 20 December 2007|access-date=14 April 2010 |location=Edinburgh}}</ref> According to a 2012 poll, 25% of the [[Turks in Germany]] believe atheists are inferior human beings.<ref>Liljeberg Research International: [https://d171.keyingress.de/multimedia/document/228.pdf ''Deutsch-Türkische Lebens und Wertewelten 2012''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011112234/https://d171.keyingress.de/multimedia/document/228.pdf |date=11 October 2012 }}, July/August 2012, p. 68</ref><ref>[[Die Welt]]: [https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article108659406/Tuerkische-Migranten-hoffen-auf-muslimische-Mehrheit.html ''Türkische Migranten hoffen auf muslimische Mehrheit''], 17 August 2012, retrieved 23 August 2012</ref> Portugal has elected two presidents, [[Mário Soares]], who was also elected Prime-Minister, and [[Jorge Sampaio]], who have openly expressed their irreligion, as well as two agnostic Prime-Ministers, [[José Sócrates]] and [[António Costa]]. On the contrary, in Greece, the right-wing New Democracy government stated that "the Greek people have a right to know whether Mr. [[Alexis Tsipras|Tsipras]] is an atheist", citing their political opponent's irreligiosity as a reason he should not be elected, even though they granted that "it is his right."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/250179/nd-o-ellinikos-prepei-na-gnorizei-an-o-tsipras-einai-atheosd/|title=ΝΔ: Ο ελληνικός λαός πρέπει να γνωρίζει αν ο Τσίπρας είναι άθεος – η απάντηση ΣΥΡΙΖΑ|work=skai.gr|date=19 January 2014 }}</ref> In the [[Elder Pastitsios]] case, a 27-year-old was sentenced to imprisonment for satirizing a popular apocalyptically-minded Greek Orthodox monk, while several [[Metropolitan bishop|metropolitans]] of the Greek Orthodox Church (which is not separated from the state) have also urged their flock "not to vote unbelievers into office", even going so far as to warn Greek Orthodox laymen that they would be "sinning if they voted atheists into public office."{{cn|date=November 2021}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.topontiki.gr/article/65820|title=Μητροπολίτης Γόρτυνος: "Το ράσο μου πετάει τριφασικό ρεύμα" (Video)|access-date=5 March 2015}}</ref>
====Brazil==== {{Further|Irreligion in Brazil}} A 2009 survey showed that atheists were the most hated demographic group in Brazil, among several other minorities polled, being almost on par with drug addicts. According to the research, 17% of the interviewees stated they felt either hatred or repulsion for atheists, while 25% felt antipathy and 29% were indifferent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.paulopes.com.br/2009/05/ateus-e-usuarios-de-drogas-sao-os-mais.html|title=Ateus e drogados são os mais odiados pelos brasileiros|work=Paulopes.com.br|date=3 May 2009|access-date=4 August 2013|language=pt}}</ref>

====Bangladesh==== {{main|Attacks on secularists in Bangladesh}} {{See also|Persecution of atheists in Bangladesh|Religion in Bangladesh#Atheism|Freedom of religion in Bangladesh#Persecution of atheists}} The [[Constitution of Bangladesh]] ensures [[secularism]] and right to religious freedom.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Constitution of the People's Republic of Bangladesh|url=http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/act-367.html|access-date=2020-07-01|website=bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd}}</ref> Yet, the controversial [[Digital Security Act]] (DSA), passed in 2018, provides provisions against blasphemous expressions:
:Article 28, Section 1<br />"If any person or group willingly or knowingly publishes or broadcasts or causes to publish or broadcast anything in website or any electronic format which hurts religious sentiment or values, with an intention to hurt or provoke the religious values or sentiments, then such act of the person shall be an offence."<ref name="dsabd">{{Cite web|title=Digital Security Act 2020|url=https://www.cirt.gov.bd/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Digital-Security-Act-2020.pdf|access-date=2021-04-26|website=www.cirt.gov.bd}}</ref>
The penalty under Section 2 and 3 of Article 28 of the Digital Security Act is a term of imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine of [[Bangladeshi taka|BDT]] 1 million, or both. A person that commits the same offense several times is subject to imprisonment for up to 10 years or a “fine not exceeding Taka 20 lac (BDT 2 Million), or with both.”<ref name="dsabd" /> Allegedly, DSA is being used to prosecute any person for atheistic remarks.
Religious Education is a mandatory subject in Bangladeshi public curricula from Grade-3 (Ages 8 to 9 usually), and even though Religious Education is required from Grade-3 onwards, most public and private schools have Religious Education since Grade-1 (Ages 6 to 7 usually), and most children are given Religious Education from a young age, and most children from Muslim households in Bangladesh can read the Qur'an by the time they are 8 or 9. Religion is also a mandatory elective needed in order for a student to sit for their [[Secondary School Certificate#Bangladesh|SSCs]]. Although Atheism is frowned upon, no atheists have ever been given death sentence for apostasy since the birth of the country. Some Bangladeshi atheists have been assassinated by various local Islamic extremist organizations, but the Government has taken strict measures and has since banned the Islamist groups.<ref>{{Cite web|last=bdnews24.com|first=Staff Correspondent|title=Ansar al-Islam banned in Bangladesh|url=https://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2017/03/05/ansar-al-islam-banned-in-bangladesh|access-date=2020-07-01|website=bdnews24.com}}</ref>

===Other=== [[Regular Freemasonry]] insists among other things that a volume of scripture is open in a working lodge, that every member profess belief in a Supreme Being, and that the discussion of religion is banned. [[Continental Freemasonry]] is now the general term for the "liberal" jurisdictions which have removed some, or all, of these restrictions.
"Duty to God" is a [[Scout method#Principles|principle of Scouting]] worldwide, though it is applied differently among countries.<ref name="faqs">{{cite web | year=1998 | url=http://www.faqs.org/faqs/scouting/rec.scouting.issues/section-11.html | title = What was Baden-Powell's position on God and Religion in Scouting? | publisher = Faqs | access-date = 2006-12-03}}</ref><ref name="inquiry">{{cite web |last=Baden-Powell |first=Robert |year=1912 |url=http://www.inquiry.net/ideals/b-p/religion.htm |title=Baden-Powell on Religion |publisher= Inquiry.net |access-date=2006-12-03 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061115192441/http://www.inquiry.net/ideals/b-p/religion.htm |archive-date=2006-11-15}}</ref> The [[Boy Scouts of America]] (BSA) takes a strong position, excluding atheists and [[agnostics]],<ref name="duty">{{cite web|url=http://www.bsalegal.org/dutytogo-155.htm|work=BSA Legal Issues|title=Duty to God|publisher=Boy Scouts of America|access-date=2006-12-03|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060827022542/http://www.bsalegal.org/dutytogo-155.htm|archive-date=2006-08-27}}</ref><ref name="dutytogod">{{cite web | url = http://www.bsa-discrimination.org/html/god-top.html | title = BSA and Religious Belief | publisher = BSA Discrimination.org | url-status=dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070120110841/http://www.bsa-discrimination.org/html/god-top.html | archive-date = 20 January 2007 | date = 22 January 2005 }}</ref> while [[Girl Scouts of the USA]] takes a more neutral position. The [[The Scout Association|United Kingdom Scout Association]] has recently published alternative promises for people of different or no religion, specifying "Atheists, Humanists and people of no specific religion", who make a promise to uphold Scouting values rather than a duty to God. [[Scouts Canada]] defines Duty to God broadly in terms of "adherence to spiritual principles" and does not require members to be part of an organized religion, but does require that they have some form of "personal spirituality".<ref name="bscfaq">{{cite web| url=https://www.scouts.ca/about/faq.html |title=Scouts Canada FAQ | publisher = Scouts Canada | access-date= 20 June 2019}}</ref> In other countries, especially in Europe, some Scouting organizations may be [[secularism|secularist]] or religiously neutral (such as [[Eclaireuses et Eclaireurs de France]], [[Corpo Nazionale Giovani Esploratori ed Esploratrici Italiani]] and the ''Baden-Powell Service Association'' in the United States<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bpsa-us.org/policies-and-guidelines|title=BPSA-US Policy & Guidelines}}</ref>).
